doc.after: Around 971, Emperor John I Tzimiskes established the theme or "district" of Paristrion in the territories occupied between the Balkan Mountains and the Lower Danube.[310][311] Naval bases were built at Capidava, Noviodunum, and PÄcuiul lui Soare on the river.[312] Bulgarians and Vlachs living in the annexed territories often expressed their hostility towards imperial rule.[313] Anna Comnena relates how local Vlachs showed "the way through the passes"[314] of the Balkan Mountains to invading Cumans in 1094.[315] All the same, Vlachs served in the imperial army,[316] for instance during an imperial campaign against the Kingdom of Hungary in 1166.[317] New taxes imposed by imperial authorities caused a rebellion of Vlachs and Bulgarians in 1185,[318] which led to the establishment of the Second Bulgarian Empire.[319] The Vlachs' eminent status within the new state is evidenced by the writings of Robert of Clari and other western authors,[320] who refer either to the new state or to its mountainous regions as "Vlachia" until the 1250s.[320]
